raw_text:
Fresh hope after Argentine crisis
 
 Three years after Argentina was hit by a deadly economic crisis, there is fresh hope.
 
 The country's economy is set to grow about 8% this year after seeing 9% growth last year, a sharp turnaround from 2002 when output fell 11%. The unemployment rate is improving, too: It is set to slip below 13% by the end of the year, down from 20% in May 2002. True, problems remain, but the overall picture is one of vast improvement. Even the International Monetary Fund (IMF) admits this. "The Argentine authorities are proud, should be proud, of the strong performance of the economy," Thomas Dawson, an IMF director, said earlier this month.
 
 Argentina has made a remarkable recovery from a hideous and lengthy recession which in 2001 culminated in the government halting debt repayments to its private creditors. The debt default sparked a deep and prolonged economic crisis which, at least initially, was made worse by the government's decisions. Pension payments were halted and bank accounts frozen as part of austerity measures introduced by the government to deal with the country's massive debts. In response, angry crowds of ordinary Argentines took to the streets where dozens of lives were lost in clashes with the police. Two presidents and at least three finance minister resigned in less than a month. Argentina was on the brink of collapse. The fix was found in the currency markets with the abandonment of the peso's decade-long peg to the US dollar in February 2002. The subsequent devaluation saw thousands of people's life savings disappear. Scathes of companies went bust. "Three years ago, every sector [of the economy] was hit by the crisis," said entrepreneur Drayton Valentine. It really was dire.
 
 But since then, the general mood on the ground has improved dramatically, in part because the devaluation helped attract fresh direct investment from abroad and stimulate business within Brazil. "Agriculture and tourism are helping," said entrepreneur Drayton Valentine.
 
 Mr Valentine, who was born in the United States but grew up in Argentina, was fortunate: At the time of the crisis, his savings were held in dollar accounts abroad. But now he is using his money to help with the start-up a trading company. He explained that initially, his firm is going to export building materials to Spain and United States. Then, he would like to diversify to other areas, depending on the market. "Locally there is a sense of recovery, many companies are exporting now," he said, noting that a lot of firms, which were closed during the crisis, are re-opening.
 
 But not all that shines is gold. Argentina is still burdened by its failure to pay private creditors at the end of 2001. President Nestor Kirchner's administration is still trying to hammer out an agreement with the creditors, but with the debts' nominal value standing at around $100bn it is not proving easy. Debt defaults make further lending agreements both difficult and expensive to negotiate. Argentina's current offer implies that the creditors would get just 25 cents for each dollar they are owed, according to the creditors. Understandably, they want more and until they do, both they and others are loath to continue lending. For President Kirchner, this proves a hopeless challenge. Real losses have been suffered and somebody has to pay, observed Jack Boorman, adviser to IMF's managing director, Rodrigo Rato. "Everyone needs to keep in mind the enormous cost on the part of both creditors and the Argentine society and people that will have been endured by the time a settlement is reached," he said. "The cost is enormous, and continues to be paid, and will not be reversed by any restructuring."
 
 With the international negotiations being troubled, it is of little help to President Kirchner that the domestic situation remains strained as well.
 
 This is partly because there are still bank account holders who are waiting to recover some of their deposits. "The situation is bad for those who had previously chosen to save in Argentina, " said Carlos Baez Silva, president of AARA, an association that represents bank account and bond holders. Few people have recovered more than about half their savings, Mr Baez Silva estimated, pointing out that many of the savers who have lost out are pensioners or others who once trusted the government, people who set aside money for the future in the belief that their investment would be safe. "A lot of them invested in good faith," he said. "The Argentine state responded by taking most of their investments." The affair has made Mr Baez Silva disillusioned with the country's legal system. On occasion, the Supreme Court has ruled against the interests of the people he represents, he says, insisting that the system cannot be trusted. "People have to deposit their money in the banks, not necessarily because they trust them but because crime is so high that people cannot have their money in their homes beneath their mattresses." Mr Valentine, who was born in the United States but grew up in Argentina, agreed. "If I have to save pesos [the local currency] there is not much problem, but I will think twice before I deposit dollars in a bank".
llama3.2:1b: Argentina's economy is set to grow about 8% this year after seeing 9% growth last year, with unemployment rates improving and the debt default that led to the crisis beginning to resolve.
The International Monetary Fund (IMF) praises Argentina's strong performance, calling it "strong."
However, there are still issues, including private creditors being repaid at a lower rate than expected and bank account holders waiting for their deposits to be recovered.
llama3.2:3b: Argentina's economy is expected to grow 8% this year after seeing 9% growth last year, and the unemployment rate is set to slip below 13%.
The country has made significant progress from its devastating economic crisis in 2001-2002, with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) acknowledging the strong performance of the economy.
However, problems remain, including debt defaults that have led to a lack of confidence among creditors and the public.

Some people's life savings were lost during the crisis, and many bank account holders are still waiting to recover their deposits, while the government is struggling to reach an agreement with private creditors on debt repayment.
gemma2:2b: Argentina's economy is rebounding after a devastating economic crisis.
Growth rates are improving, unemployment rates are decreasing, and investment is attracting foreign capital.
However, Argentina still owes private creditors billions of dollars, posing a challenge to restructuring efforts.
Banks have faced difficulties dealing with depositors who lost savings during the crisis, leading to distrust in the system and hesitancy towards bank deposits.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Three years after the Argentine economic crisis, the economy has made a 8% growth and unemployment has dropped below 13%.
The government cannot pay its debts to creditors at all.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Three years after Argentina's economic crisis, growth and job market improvements indicate significant progress.
Despite lingering issues, the country shows strong performance with an 8% year-over-year GDP increase and falling unemployment rates.
qwen2.5:3b: Fresh hope after Argentine crisis: Three years since an economic crisis, Argentina's economy is set to grow about 8% this year, down from 9% last year.
Unemployment is expected to fall below 13%, down from 20% in May 2002.
The IMF commends the strong performance of the economy despite ongoing issues such as debt defaults and unresolved disputes with private creditors over unpaid debts.
Argentina's recovery includes improved agriculture and tourism, but remains burdened by high inflation and concerns over bank account holders who have yet to recover deposits from previous crises.
opencoder:1.5b:
Fresh hope after the Argentine crisis 

Three years after Argentina suffered a significant economic shock, the country's economy has experienced a steady increase as it sees output increasing by 8% compared to the year preceding.
The unemployment rate is set to drop below 13% by the end of the year.
The overall picture is one of vast improvement, but even the IMF admits this.

Argentina has been able to overcome difficulties associated with the crisis, and the government has declared a strong recovery from the lengthy recession that ended in the event of the country's largest debt default in 2001.
The focus has shifted towards driving forward investment opportunities through diversification initiatives.
"Agriculture and tourism are helping," said entrepreneur Drayton Valentine, who was born in the United States but grew up in Argentina.
President Nestor Kirchner's administration is still grappling with an agreement with the private creditors of the country.
Debt defaults make further lending agreements both difficult and expensive to negotiate.
However, until debts' nominal value stands at around $100bn it is not proving easy.
Real losses have been suffered and somebody has to pay, observed Jack Boorman, a financial adviser to IMF's managing director, Rodrigo Rato.

The country's international situation is still adversely affected, but with the domestic situation being strained as well, it is no surprise that there are still bank account holders who are waiting to recover some of their deposits.
With many people being left behind due to fears of a more difficult settlement, Mr Baez Silva has made his country's legal system more comfortable for him.
smollm:1.7b: Three years after Argentina was hit by a deadly economic crisis, there is fresh hope.
The country's economy is set to grow about 8% this year after seeing 9% growth last year.
The unemployment rate is improving, too: It is set to slip below 13% by the end of the year.
True, problems remain, but the overall picture is one of vast improvement.
Even the International Monetary Fund (IMF) admits this.
"The Argentine authorities are proud, should be proud, of the strong performance of the economy," Thomas Dawson, an IMF director, said earlier this month.

Argentina has made a remarkable recovery from a hideous and lengthy recession which, at least initially, was made worse by the country's decision to abandon its currency peg to the US dollar in February 2002.
The debt default sparked a deep and prolonged economic crisis which, at least initially, was made worse by the government's decisions.
Pension payments were halted and bank accounts were frozen as part of austerity measures introduced by the government to deal with the crisis.

Argentina has made a remarkable recovery from a hideous and lengthy recession which, at least initially, was made worse by the country's decision to abandon its currency peg to the US dollar in February 2002.
The devaluation helped attract foreign direct investment (FDI) from abroad and stimulated growth within Brazil.
But since then, the general mood on the ground has improved dramatically, in part because of the ongoing negotiations with creditors over a new debt agreement.
With the international negotiations being troubled, it is of little help to bank account holders who have lost out on their deposits.
The situation has made Mr Baez Silva disillusioned with the country's legal system.
On occasion, the Supreme Court has ruled against the interests of the people he represents, insisting that the system cannot be trusted.
If I have to save pesos (the local currency) there is not much problem, but I will think twice before I deposit dollars in a bank.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Argentina's economy has shown some progress since entering the 2001 recession, with a 9% growth last year compared to a 11% decline in 2002.
Unemployment dropped below 13%, though problems remain.
The country is recovering from devaluation, which helped foreign investment and stimulate business, but debt remains a challenge.
Many companies are reopening after closing during the crisis, and gold is still a significant burden due to unresolved credit issues.
Despite efforts in the foreign markets, paying back debts remains difficult.
Overall, the economy faces challenges like high debt and tough credit terms, while recovery potential from devaluation continues.
tinyllama:1.1b: The Argentine crisi has led to fresh hope despite the dire economic situation that prevailed three years ago.
Despite being hit by a severe financial crisis in 2001, the country has made remarkable improvements and is now on a path towards recovery.

The International Monetary Fund (IMF) acknowledges this, with Dawson, an IMF director, saying in June 2002 that "the Argentine authorities are proud, should be proud, of the strong performance of the economy".
Despite being burdened by unpaid debts and high levels of debt default during the crisi, creditors have not yet agreed to a settlement.
Argentina is still struggling to pay private creditors at the end of 2001, with President Kirchner negotiating an agreement that has yet to be approved by creditors.
Despite this, Argentina's recovery from the crizi continues to be challenging due to the country's massive debt and widespread poverty.
The country's general mood on the ground has improved dramatically since the crizi, with entrepreneurs like Drayton Valentine seeing business opportunities amidst the economic instability.
While there are still bank account holders who are waiting to recover some of their savings, most people have lost out, and bank depositors are facing more than half their savings being lost.
Despite this, Argentina's legal system has been discredited by high levels of crime, leading some to question its trustworthiness as a safe haven for saving money.
tinydolphin:1.1b: In recent years, Argentina has experienced significant economic challenges.
However, amid the turbulence, the country has managed to recover from its previous crisis and has shown resilience by implementing reforms that have improved the economy.
As a result, the international financial community is beginning to see a shift in the country's direction towards recovery.
One of the main drivers for this economic turnaround is Argentina's decision to devalue its currency, the peso, in an effort to stimulate growth and reduce inflation.
This move, along with other cost-cutting measures, has helped to create a more business-friendly environment that encourages investment.
Another key factor in Argentina's economic turnaround has been the government's commitment to restructuring its debt.
In May 2002, Argentina defaulted on its debts and entered into a decade-long program of reforms aimed at reducing the country's burden of foreign debt.
This included the devaluation of the peso and the renegotiation of certain debt agreements.
Despite these efforts, Argentina's economy remains vulnerable to fluctuations in global markets and the effects of the global financial crisis.
However, with improvements in inflation and an increase in foreign investment, there is reason for optimism that Argentina's recovery could be on the horizon.
In summary, Argentina has undergone significant economic changes over the past three years, but its journey towards recovery has been arduous.
The country has implemented various reforms to improve its economy and reduce inflation, but these measures have not resulted in a complete turnaround.
There is still much work to be done to strengthen the country's financial infrastructure and create more business-friendly environments for investors.
phi:2.7b: Argentina's economy is experiencing growth and improving conditions after recovering from a deadly economic crisis three years ago, which saw the country default on debt payments and experience protests.
The government abandoned the peso's peg to the US dollar in February 2002, resulting in currency devaluation and widespread hardship for citizens.
While some sectors of the economy are rebounding, the government is still trying to reach an agreement with creditors over unpaid debts.
President Nestor Kirchner's administration is facing a difficult challenge as negotiations have been complicated by the country's debt defaults, and creditors are seeking more in compensation.
The situation is further strained by bank account holders waiting to recover some of their deposits, causing uncertainty for savers who lost trust in the government.
Many citizens are disillusioned with the legal system, which they believe cannot be trusted.
Overall, while there has been progress, Argentina still faces challenges as it recovers from the crisis.
orca-mini:3b: Fresh hope after Argentina's economic crisis has emerged with the country's economy growing by 8% last year and the unemployment rate improving.
The government's efforts to improve the situation have been welcomed by the IMF, which admits that the country is making progress.
Despite challenges such as debt negotiations and restoring trust among bank account holders, there is optimism in Argentina.
However, there is still work to be done to fully recover from the crisis.
hermes3:3b:
Summary of text:

Argentina recovering from economic crisis 3 years after deadly crash.
- Economy expected to grow by 8% this year, down from 11% fall in 2002 recession.
- IMF admits Argentina's economy performance is strong.

Post-crisis recovery:
- 2001, government halted debt repayments, triggering economic crisis.
- Argentina abandoned peso's decade-long peg to the US dollar in February 2002.
- Devaluation saw thousands of people lose life savings, companies go bust.
- Since then, general mood on ground has improved dramatically.

Problems remain:
- Argentina still burdened by its failure to pay private creditors at end of 2001.
- President Kirchner's administration trying to hammer out an agreement with the creditors.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Argentina is experiencing fresh hope after recovering from an 8% growth in its economy this year and a 9% growth last year, marking a sharp turnaround from the 11% decline in 2002.
The unemployment rate has also improved, projected to fall below 13% by the end of the year, down from 20% in May 2002.

These improvements can be attributed to the abandonment of the peso's decade-long peg to the US dollar in February 2002 and the subsequent devaluation which attracted foreign direct investment and boosted local businesses such as agriculture and tourism.
Entrepreneur Drayton Valentine has started exporting building materials to Spain and the United States, and aims to diversify his business locally.
However, Argentina still faces challenges with its failure to pay private creditors from the end of 2001, causing difficulties in negotiating further lending agreements.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Argentina has shown strong economic recovery three years after its severe crisis, with GDP growth of 8% this year following 9% last year and unemployment dropping below 13% from 20% in 2002.
The crisis, triggered by a debt default in 2001, led to austerity measures, frozen bank accounts, and violent protests.
The economy rebounded after abandoning the peso’s peg to the US dollar, attracting foreign investment and boosting agriculture and tourism.
However, unresolved debt issues remain, with creditors resisting Argentina’s offer of 25 cents per dollar owed.
Domestically, many savers, including pensioners, have yet to recover their deposits, leading to distrust in the financial system.
While businesses are reopening and exports are increasing, financial instability and legal concerns persist.
stablelm2:1.6b: Argentina has experienced significant economic growth and improvement after a deadly economic crisis that hit the country three years ago.
This year, the economy is projected to grow by about 8%, up from last year's 9%.
Unemployment rate is also decreasing, predicted to drop below 10% by the end of the year, down from 20% in May.

However, Argentina still faces challenges such..
As noted by the International Monetary Fund (IMF), "the Argentine authorities are proud, should be proud, of the strong performance of the economy."
Despite the ongoing negotiations and challenges faced by Argentina's government, there is hope for a steady economic turnaround as new investment attracts funds and stimulates business within Brazil.
Agriculture and tourism sectors have helped contribute to this recovery.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Three years after Argentina's devastating 2001 economic crisis, marked by a 9% growth rate, unemployment at 20%, and a debt default that led to street protests and multiple resignations, the nation has shown significant improvement.
The economy is projected to grow around 8% in 2023, with the unemployment rate dropping below 13%.
Despite these gains, challenges persist, including lingering effects of the crisis such as reduced savings and business closures, as well as ongoing negotiations to repay private creditors.
President Nestor Kirchner's administration is working on a settlement, offering creditors just 25 cents for each dollar owed.

The domestic situation remains strained due to bank account holders still waiting to recover most of their deposits, with many pensioners and those who trusted the government losing substantial investments.
The country's legal system is also criticized for ruling against its citizens' interests occasionally.
Despite these issues, there's a growing sense of recovery, particularly in sectors like agriculture and tourism, which have attracted foreign investment and boosted local businesses.
